Listen to U.S. Supreme Court arguments from April 2017, provided by The Oyez Project.
Listen to U.S. Supreme Court arguments from April 2017, provided by The Oyez Project.View this email in your browser
 

News From the Court

Neil Gorsuch took two oaths of office in April to become a Supreme Court Justice, as covered in an article by the ABA Journal. The Associated Press also reported on Gorsuch’s first days on the bench, discussing the cases he heard and the questions he asked during oral arguments.

Clash of the Titans: Supreme Court heavyweights Tom Goldstein argued against Paul Clement on April 17th in California Public Employees’ Retirement System v. ANZ Securities – listen to the oral argument here.

“Oh come on,” a shocked Chief Justice Roberts exclaimed during questioning of Robert A. Parker, a Justice Department lawyer in Maslenjak v. United States. The exchange was among several moments of indignation and incredulity during oral argument over the Government’s unyielding position that American citizenship may be revoked over trivial misstatements made in naturalization proceedings. Listen to the oral argument here.

Justia columnist and Cornell Law professor Sherry F. Colb writes about Moore v. Texas, in which the Supreme Court endorsed a standard because it was factually more accurate than a prior standard (which is, perhaps surprisingly, not the norm). Read her column here.

Michael C. Dorf, another Justia columnist and Cornell Law professor, writes about a recent Supreme Court decision, Expressions Hair Design v. Schneiderman, regarding New York credit card surcharge laws as free speech. Read his column here.

Constitutional law scholar Erwin Chemerinsky discusses Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. v. Superior Court of California, a case in which the Court must decide when state courts can assert jurisdiction over out-of-state parties. Read the article here.

Forbes reports on the Supreme Court’s recent decision in Lewis v. Clarke, refusing to extend tribal immunity to a casino limo driver.

The Supreme Court majority opinion in Nelson v. Colorado held that the state of Colorado must return fines and costs assessed against criminal defendants whose convictions have been reversed. Read the analysis from Forbes here.

ABA Journal reports on the Supreme Court’s decision in Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. v. Haeger, overturning a $2.7 million sanction for discovery misconduct. The sanction was originally imposed by a federal judge in Arizona for Goodyear’s failure to disclose the results of tire tests during discovery in a suit involving a motor home crash.

Arguments

Perry v. Merit Systems Protection Bd. (4/17/17)
Is a Merit Systems Protection Board decision disposing of an employment discrimination case on jurisdictional grounds subject to judicial review in district court or in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit?

Town of Chester v. Laroe Estates (4/17/17)
According to Article III of the U.S. Constitution, must intervenors to a lawsuit establish standing on their own, or may they join so long as there is a valid case or controversy between the named parties?

California Public Employees’ Retirement System v. ANZ Securities (4/17/17)

  1. Does the filing of a putative class action lawsuit serve to satisfy the three-year time limit in Section 13 of the Securities Act with respect to the individual claims of other class members?
  2. May a member of a timely filed putative class action suit file an individual suit on the same causes of action before class certification is decided, as long as all time limits are met?

Kokesh v. SEC (4/18/17)
Does the five-year statute of limitations of 28 U.S.C. §2462 apply to claims brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking repayment of illegally obtained funds?

Henson v. Santander Consumer USA (4/18/17)
Is a company that regularly attempts to collect debts it purchased after the debts had fallen into default is a “debt collector” subject to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act?

Trinity Lutheran Church v. Comer (4/19/17)
Does the exclusion of churches from an otherwise neutral and secular aid program violate the First Amendment’s guarantee of free exercise of religion and the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause?

Weaver v. Massachusetts (4/19/17)
Must a defendant who asserts a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel demonstrate prejudice when the alleged ineffective assistance resulted in a structural error?

McWilliams v. Dunn (4/24/17)
Does the Supreme Court’s decision in Ake v. Oklahoma, which established that an indigent defendant is entitled to meaningful expert assistance, require that the expert be independent of the prosecution?

Davila v. Davis (4/24/17)
Should the Supreme Court’s precedent that ineffective state habeas counsel can overcome the procedural default of an ineffective assistance of trial claim also apply to the procedural default of claims of ineffective assistance of appellate counsel?

Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. v. Superior Court of California (4/25/17)
Do a plaintiff’s claims sufficiently arise out of or relate to a defendant’s forum activities to create specific jurisdiction when the plaintiff’s claims would be exactly the same even if the defendant had no forum contacts?

BNSF Railway Co. v. Tyrrell (4/25/17)
In a suit filed under the Federal Employers’ Liability Act,can a state court decline to follow the U.S. Supreme Court precedent of Daimler AG v. Bauman, which held that a state court cannot exercise personal jurisdiction over a defendant that is not “at home” in the forum state?

Sandoz Inc. v. Amgen Inc. (4/26/17)

  1. Under the Biologics Price Competition and Innovation Act of 2009, can notice of commercial marketing of a “biosimilar product” be effective if given prior to approval by the Food and Drug Administration?
  2. Does the notice requirement delay sale of biosimilar products by 180 days after notice?
  3. Does the Act only permit a remedy for a claim of patent infringement?

Maslenjak v. United States (4/26/17)
May a naturalized American citizen be stripped of her citizenship in a criminal proceeding based on an immaterial false statement?

Cert Granted

2017 Term
Jenser v. Arab Bank (4/3/17)

Ayestes v. Davis (4/3/17)

Decisions

Coventry Health Care of Missouri, Inc. v. Nevils (4/18/17)
The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act (FEHBA) preempts state laws that prohibit insurance companies from claiming the proceeds of personal injury settlements pursuant to their contracts, and the express preemption clause of the FEHBA does not violate the Supremacy Clause. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg delivered the opinion of the 8-0 majority.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/16-149/opinion3.html

Dean v. United States (4/3/17)
A sentencing court may use its discretion when calculating an appropriate sentence for a felony serving as the basis for a conviction under 18 U.S.C. §924(c). Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr., delivered the opinion for the unanimous Court, which held that §924(c) did not prevent sentencing courts from exercising the discretion that they have traditionally enjoyed when tasked with evaluating factors of a case.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/15-9260/opinion3.html

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. v. Haeger (4/18/17)
An unreasonable delay in litigation is not a defense against a claim for damages brought within the six-year statutory period of limitations in a patent infringement case. Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr., delivered the opinion of the 7-1 majority.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/15-1406/opinion3.html

Lewis v. Clarke (4/25/17)
Tribal sovereign immunity is not implicated in a suit against a tribal employee in his individual capacity, and an indemnification provision cannot extend tribal sovereign immunity to conduct that it would not otherwise cover. Justice Sonia Sotomayor delivered the opinion of the 8-0 majority.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/15-1500/opinion3.html

McLane Co. v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (4/3/17)
A district court’s determination on whether to enforce an Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) subpoena should be reviewed for abuse of discretion, which gives deference to the lower court’s determination. Justice Sonia Sotomayor delivered the opinion for the 7-1 majority.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/15-1248/opinion3.html

Manrique v. United States (4/19/17)
Appellate courts may not review a restitution award where the amended judgment of the lower court granting restitution is entered after notice of appeal was filed. Justice Clarence Thomas delivered the opinion for the 6-2 majority.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/15-7250/opinion3.html

Nelson v. Colorado (4/19/17)
Colorado’s Exoneration Act, which requires exonerated persons to “prove, by clear and convincing evidence, that they were ‘actually innocent’” in order to refund their money, is invalid under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg delivered the opinion for the 7-1 majority.

Decision: https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/581/15-1256/opinion3.html
